comparable to 100 centesimi.', 'Dinar - Some dinars, like the Kuwaiti and Yemeni, have subunits where one unit equals 100 fils.', 'Rial - In some countries, such as Afghanistan, Iraq, or Iran (prior to their currency unification), a rial can be divided into one hundred smaller units called filas or faliyas; equivalent to 100 centesimi.', 'Scellino - The former subunit of the Italian lira before its replacement by euros, worth one-hundredth of a lira (previously equal to 100 cents).', 'Schilling - A historical currency in Austria and other regions, with some varieties having 100 smaller units called heller or halper.', 'Quetzal - The currency unit used by Guatemala, divided into one-hundred centavos (cents) before it was replaced by the "quetzal" in 1925.', 'Rupiah - In some countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, a rupiah can be subdivided into one hundred sen; although nowadays they are typically not divided this way.', 'Aik - The currency of the former Soviet Republics in Asia, which could be divided into 100 kopeks or rublos before it was replaced by other currencies.', 'Bhaviyaa - The Indian currency unit "Bharat," equivalent to a rupee, can technically be divided into one hundred paisa until its demonetization in 2016.', 'Peso-Real - A former monetary unit of the Portuguese Empire (1704–1911), which was worth one thousand reales, with each reálo equivalent to 1/80th of a cruzeiro transitorio.', 'Guilder - The Dutch currency subunit known as "stuiver," where 100 stuivers equaled one gulden before the euro was introduced in the Netherlands.', 'Forint - Hungarian forint, which historically included a smaller unit called fillér (1/100th of an adópengő), but now is not divided into subunits like this.', 'Banco - The former currency of several Spanish-speaking countries such as Argentina and Uruguay, where "banco" referred to the larger coins equivalent to 100 centavos (centesimos).', 'Escudo - Portuguese escudo was a unit equivalent to one hundred cruzeiros before it was replaced by the euro in Portugal;
